repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Sometimes you want to apply treesitter highlighting to non-buffer text (such as foldtext or the message area). The problem is that there is currently no easy way to get the treesitter highlighting except for implementing a function yourself. So let's add such a function.

It has been brought to my attention that this feature is also useful for applying a highlight to a specific region in a buffer, by getting the text in the region, parsing it, getting the highlights, and setting the highlights as extmarks.

comment_data.body: `parser` is a `vim.treesitter.LanguageTree`, which is already a complex object. Should this instead be a method on that object?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -466,4 +466,74 @@ function M.foldexpr(lnum)
   return M._fold.foldexpr(lnum)
 end
 
+---@param parser vim.treesitter.LanguageTree
+---@return {group:string,range:integer[]}[]
+function M.get_text_highlight(parser)

comment_data.body: Ok
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -466,4 +466,74 @@ function M.foldexpr(lnum)
   return M._fold.foldexpr(lnum)
 end
 
+---@param parser vim.treesitter.LanguageTree
+---@return {group:string,range:integer[]}[]
+function M.get_text_highlight(parser)

comment_data.body:
Since this has 6 fields, it would be much more readable as a `@class`.

`binary_find` can also be pulled out as a put function with `stack` as an argument.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1184,4 +1184,104 @@ function LanguageTree:language_for_range(range)
   return self
 end
 
+--- Get highlight information from parser.
+---
+---@return {group:string, range:integer[]}
+function LanguageTree:get_highlight()
+  ---@type {group:string,range:integer[],priority:integer,type:'start'|'end',start?:table,subpriority:integer}[]
+  local positions = {}
+  self:for_each_tree(function(tree, ltree)
+    local source = ltree:source()
+    local hl_query = query.get(ltree:lang(), 'highlights')
+
+    if not hl_query then
+      return
+    end
+
+    for id, node, metadata in hl_query:iter_captures(tree:root(), source, 0, -1) do
+      local name = hl_query.captures[id]
+      local start_row, start_col, end_row, end_col = node:range()
+      local priority = tonumber(metadata.priority or vim.highlight.priorities.treesitter)
+
+      table.insert(positions, {
+        group = '@' .. name .. '.' .. ltree:lang(),
+        range = { start_row, start_col },
+        priority = priority,
+        subpriority = #positions,
+        type = 'start',
+      })
+
+      table.insert(positions, {
+        group = '@' .. name .. '.' .. ltree:lang(),
+        range = { end_row, end_col },
+        priority = priority,
+        subpriority = #positions - 1,
+        type = 'end',
+      })
+    end
+  end)
+
+  table.sort(positions, function(a, b)
+    return a.range[1] < b.range[1]
+      or (a.range[1] == b.range[1] and a.range[2] < b.range[2])
+      or (
+        a.range[1] == b.range[1]
+        and a.range[2] == b.range[2]
+        and a.type == 'start'
+        and b.type == 'end'
+      )
+  end)
+
+  local result = {}
+  ---@type  {group:string,range:integer[],priority:integer,type:'start'|'end',start?:table,subpriority:integer}[]

comment_data.body: Is there a reason we need to inject two elements into `positions` instead of just providing the full range?

comment_data.body:
That's how the algorithm works.

The algorithm resolves node priorities so that no node's range overlaps with another.

More about the algorithm:
A list of positions is prepared where each element is either a node's beginning or end position.
The positions are sorted by position (this separates the beginning and end positions of the same node).
Loop over the positions:
When encountering a beginning position its associated node gets appended to a priority sorted list (higher priority positions always come before lower priority positions).
When encountering an ending position its associated node gets removed from the priority sorted list.
On every cycle, if there is distance between the positions, the first node (e.g. the node with the highest priority) on the priority sorted list gets appended to the highlights list with its range set to the range between the previous position in the loop and the current position in the loop.

comment_data.body: Can you make the first return type a `@class`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4,12 +4,12 @@ local Range = require('vim.treesitter._range')
 
 local ns = api.nvim_create_namespace('treesitter/highlighter')
 
----@alias vim.treesitter.highlighter.Iter fun(end_line: integer|nil): integer, TSNode, vim.treesitter.query.TSMetadata, TSQueryMatch

comment_data.body:
I know justin said to move this into the languagetree, but now there is a dependency on `highlighter.lua`, this is better placed somewhere else.

I personally think `treesitter.lua` or `highlighterlua` is probably the best place.

Shouldn't this be(?):

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1184,4 +1184,140 @@ function LanguageTree:language_for_range(range)
   return self
 end
 
+--- Get highlight information from parser.
+---
+---@return {range:Range4, hl_group:string, priority:integer, conceal:string?, spell:boolean?, url:string?}[]
+function LanguageTree:get_highlight()
+  local highlights = {}
+  self:for_each_tree(function(tree, ltree)
+    local source = ltree:source()
+    local hl_query = query.get(ltree:lang(), 'highlights')
+
+    if not hl_query then
+      return
+    end
+
+    local highlighter = require('vim.treesitter.highlighter')
+    for info in highlighter._iter_highlight_info(hl_query, tree:root(), source, 0, -1) do
+      info.range = { Range.unpack4(info.range) }
+      table.insert(highlights, info)
+    end
+  end)
+  return highlights
+end
+
+---@nodoc
+---@class vim.treesitter.LanguageTree.highlight_resolve_priority.obj
+---@field group string
+---@field range integer[]
+---@field priority integer
+---@field type 'start'|'end'
+---@field start? table
+---@field subpriority integer
+---@field info table
+
+---@param stack vim.treesitter.LanguageTree.highlight_resolve_priority.obj[]
+---@param subpriority number
+---@return number

comment_data.body:
That function is for when you want to apply treesitter highlighting on non-buffer texts.
These include foldtext, notifications, and cmdline(using `g:Nvim_color_cmdline`).

But if it's not desired then I won't include this function.

comment_data.body: Not a blocker, but given this is a structure for the public API `|vim.treesitter.get_highlight()|` it would deserve a better class name rather than internal class name, say `vim.treesitter.highlighter.Info`, `vim.treesitter.get_highlight.ret`, or `vim.treesitter.HighlightInfo`, etc. Though I feel there will be something else that'd sound better.

comment_data.body:
I updated the doc to talk about how it signals that `@spell` or `@nospell` is set (depending on if it's true or false or nil) and linked to documentation that talks about these two capture groups.

Maybe it should be separated into two fields with one of them signaling that `@spell` is set and the other one signaling that `@nospell` is set instead?

comment_data.body:
> Note that `@spell` (and `@conceal`) is not technically a highlight. I would leave it out for now.

Is there some other way to get that info? Maybe we should rename the function if "highlight" is objectionable. What matters is that it gets useful info, the technical distinction seems minor?

Though I was under the impression that "highlights" are the generic name for annotations of all kinds. We introduced "decoration" but I'm not sure that is really necessary.

comment_data.body: Could we consider making this internal only for now in order to progress this easier? And by internal I just mean prefix with an `_` and not document. Plugins are free to use this in the short term to experiment with what works.

+---   - If `nil` then the highlight doesn't have a spell set
+---   - If `true` then the highlight is spell
+---   - If `false` then the highlight is nospell

comment_data.body: Sure
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4,12 +4,30 @@ local Range = require('vim.treesitter._range')
 
 local ns = api.nvim_create_namespace('treesitter/highlighter')
 
----@alias vim.treesitter.highlighter.Iter fun(end_line: integer|nil): integer, TSNode, vim.treesitter.query.TSMetadata, TSQueryMatch
+--- @class vim.treesitter.highlighter.Info

+--- The group of the highlight

+--- The priority of the highlight
+--- @field priority integer
+--- The conceal of the highlight, nil for no conceal
+--- @field conceal string?
+--- Whether the highlight is spell or not

+---   - If `true` then the highlight is spell
+---   - If `false` then the highlight is nospell

comment_regular_data.body: Thank you, but what's the point of this function? (Needs to be explained in the PR description and commit message.) We don't add API functions "just because we can".
